title: IS415-Project:Project Proposal: Geospatial Analysis of Income Inequality and School Completion Rates in Malaysia
text:
Intuitively, education plays a critical role in determining future economic opportunities and might be influenced by socio-economic conditions such as income inequality. However, school completion rates vary significantly across districts in Malaysia.
This project aims to explore the spatial relationship between income inequality, school completion rates and crime rates, with the goal of identifying districts where disparities are most pronounced. By using geospatial methods, we seek to uncover spatial patterns that can help policymakers target interventions more effectively.

title: IS415-Project:Project Proposal: Geospatial Analysis of Income Inequality and School Completion Rates in Malaysia
text:
2. Problem Statement
Despite Malaysia’s advancements in education, gaps in school completion rates persist across regions. One significant factor contributing to this is income inequality. Our project aims to answer the question: How does income inequality impact school completion rates across different regions of Malaysia? Additionally, we will investigate how other factors, such as regional crime rates, may interact with these variables to further affect educational outcomes.

title: IS415-Project:Project Proposal: Geospatial Analysis of Income Inequality and School Completion Rates in Malaysia
text:
3. Related Work

3.1 Stimulating Economic Growth, Improving Quality of Life & Enhancing Youth Involvement, Proceedings of International Conference on Contemporary Economic Issues 2014, Kuala Lumpur: Malaysia.
This paper has shed some light on the relationship between poverty, education and income
inequality. While overall poverty incidence is low, pockets of poverty remains particularly
among those living in the rural areas and the Bumiputeras. The incidence of poverty declines
with the level of education attained by the head of households. This negative correlation
between education and poverty is consistent with the prediction and this highlights the
important role played by education, especially at tertiary level and higher in reducing poverty
While level of poverty declines with education, income inequality increases with education.
There is an increase in average income from group to group with more and more members
having higher education but their respective income inequalities are not as clear cut. In other
words, there exist significant differences in income inequality among sub-groups but with no
clear pattern.
Source


3.2 The Impact of Economic Growth, Education Level, and Inflation Rate on Income Inequality in Malaysia
This is an article about income inequality in Malaysia. It discusses the relationship between income inequality and economic growth, education level, and inflation rate. The Gini coefficient is used to measure income inequality. A high Gini coefficient indicates a high level of income inequality. Economic growth in wealthy countries can increase income inequality. However, income inequality in poor countries can impede economic progress.
The conclusion of the article is that economic growth, education level, and inflation rate all have an impact on income inequality in Malaysia. However, the impact of these factors varies depending on the level of economic development. In Malaysia, economic growth has led to an increase in income inequality. However, increasing education levels and reducing inflation rates can help to reduce income inequality.
Source

title: IS415-Project:Project Proposal: Geospatial Analysis of Income Inequality and School Completion Rates in Malaysia
text:
4. Data
We will leverage the following datasets from the Malaysian government’s open data platform:

Income Inequality Data: Household income inequality by district (https://data.gov.my/data-catalogue/hh_inequality_district)
School Completion Rates Data: School completion rates by state (https://data.gov.my/data-catalogue/completion_school_state)
Crime Data: Crime rates by district (https://data.gov.my/data-catalogue/crime_district)

Data cleaning and preprocessing will involve handling missing values, merging datasets by geographic regions (district or state), and ensuring consistency in temporal coverage.

title: IS415-Project:Project Proposal: Geospatial Analysis of Income Inequality and School Completion Rates in Malaysia
text:
5. Approach
This project will use R Studio as the primary platform for data analysis and visualization.
Our analysis will follow these key steps:

Exploratory Spatial Data Analysis (ESDA): Using tools like Moran’s I and Local Indicators of Spatial Association (LISA), we will identify clusters of income inequality and school completion rates to understand if they are randomly distributed or form spatial patterns.
Geographically Weighted Regression (GWR): To explore the relationship between income inequality and school completion rates, we will use GWR to assess how the strength of this relationship varies across regions. We will also include crime rates as a potential confounding variable to see how it interacts with our main variables of interest.

rename_districts <- function(data) {
  data <- data %>%
    mutate(district = case_when(
      district %in% c("Iskandar Puteri", "Nusajaya", "Johor Bahru Selatan", "Johor Bahru Utara", "Seri Alam") ~ "Johor Bahru",
      district == "Bandar Bharu" ~ "Bandar Baharu",
      district %in% c("Brickfields", "Cheras", "Dang Wangi", "Sentul", "Wangsa Maju","W.P. Kuala Lumpur") ~ "WP. Kuala Lumpur",
      district == "Nilai" ~ "Seremban",
      district == "Cameron Highland" ~ "Cameron Highlands",
      district == "Kuala Lipis" ~ "Lipis",
      district %in% c("Batu Gajah", "Ipoh") ~ "Kinta",
      district == "Gerik" ~ "Ulu Perak",
      district == "Manjung" ~ "Manjung (Dinding)",
      district == "Pangkalan Hulu" ~ "Ulu Perak",
      district %in% c("Selama", "Taiping", "Larut dan Matang") ~ "Larut Dan Matang",
      district == "Sungai Siput" ~ "Kuala Kangsar",
      district %in% c("Tanjong Malim", "Tapah", "Bagan Datuk", "Muallim") ~ "Batang Padang",
      district %in% c("Arau", "Kangar", "Padang Besar") ~ "Perlis",
      state == "Pulau Pinang" & district == "Seberang Perai Selatan" ~ "S.P.Selatan",
      district == "Seberang Perai Tengah" ~ "S.P. Tengah",
      district == "Seberang Perai Utara" ~ "S.P. Utara",
      district == "Ampang Jaya" ~ "Gombak",
      district == "Kajang" ~ "Ulu Langat",
      district %in% c("Pengkalan Hulu","Hulu Perak") ~ "Ulu Perak",
      district == "Hulu Selangor" ~ "Ulu Selangor",
      district %in% c("Klang Selatan", "Klang Utara") ~ "Klang",
      district %in% c("Petaling Jaya", "Serdang", "Sg. Buloh", "Shah Alam", "Subang Jaya", "Sungai Buloh") ~ "Petaling",
      district == "Kota Kinabatangan" ~ "Kinabatangan",
      district == "Kota Samarahan" ~ "Samarahan",
      district %in% c("Matu Daro", "Tanjung Manis") ~ "Mukah",
      district == "Padawan" ~ "Kuching",
      district == "Kulai" ~ "Kulaijaya",
      district == "Tangkak" ~ "Ledang",
      district == "Kecil Lojing" ~ "Gua Musang",
      district == "Kalabakan" ~ "Tawau",
      district == "Telupid" ~ "Beluran",
      district == "Beluru" ~ "Miri",
      district == "Bukit Mabong" ~ "Kapit",
      district == "Kabong" ~ "Saratok",
      district == "Maradong" ~ "Meradong",
      district == "Pusa" ~ "Betong",
      district == "Sebauh" ~ "Bintulu",
      district == "Subis" ~ "Miri",
      district == "Tebedu" ~ "Serian",
      district == "Telang Usan" ~ "Marudi",
      district == "Kuala Nerus" ~ "Kuala Terengganu",
      TRUE ~ district
    ))
  
  return(data)
}

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Combining Crime Type
From the initial prototype of the Shiny application, it was seen that for assault category, there was multiple types of robbery like robbery_gang_armed,robbery_gang_unarmed,robbery_solo_armed and robbery_solo_unarmed. This is the same for the property type with multiple types of vehicle theft like theft_vehicle_lorry,theft_vehicle_motorcar and theft_vehicle_motorcycle. This was causing the large file size as there are multiple rows, so we decided to combine it into a generic type robbery and vehicle_theft.As for the user it would not matter to them on the different types of robbery type or vehicle theft type

msia <- msia %>%
  mutate(cat_type = paste(category, type, sep = "-")) %>%
  select(-category, -type) %>%
  pivot_wider(
    names_from = cat_type,
    values_from = crimes,
    values_fill = 0.0,
    values_fn = mean  # Calculate the mean of duplicate values
  )


msia <- msia %>%
  mutate(
    robbery = `assault-robbery_gang_armed` + `assault-robbery_gang_unarmed` + 
              `assault-robbery_solo_armed` + `assault-robbery_solo_unarmed`,
    vehicle_theft = `property-theft_vehicle_lorry` + `property-theft_vehicle_motorcar` + 
                    `property-theft_vehicle_motorcycle`
  ) %>%
  select(-`assault-robbery_gang_armed`, -`assault-robbery_gang_unarmed`, 
         -`assault-robbery_solo_armed`, -`assault-robbery_solo_unarmed`,
         -`property-theft_vehicle_lorry`, -`property-theft_vehicle_motorcar`, 
         -`property-theft_vehicle_motorcycle`) %>%
  rename_with(~str_remove(., "^assault-|^property-"))

msia <- msia %>%
  select(-"NA-NA")

Remove NA values for the year

msia <- msia[!is.na(msia$year), ]
